;香港国泰航空周四下午提供超过 50,000 份经济舱折扣 -飞往世界各地目的地的往返机票，起价与大流行前相似。

;

;包括《华盛顿邮报》记者在内的多名争夺更便宜航班的用户表示，一旦他们登录国泰账户并选择目的地，他们就可以选择购买更便宜的机票。下午 2 点推出航班选择页面时，被告知要等一个多小时才能进入航班选择页面。

;

;另一位邮政同事 Joe Kainz 试图以 7,419 港元（美元）预订两张飞往旧金山的机票。每张票 947 美元），他说他进入了预订阶段，但网站崩溃了，他被重定向到再次等待，但放弃了。

;

;企业传播经理 Naomi Butson 是其中之一。用户在访问网站时遇到问题而放弃，然后不得不重新开始。

;

;“我感到失望，但我并不感到惊讶。现在机票价格对很多人来说都遥不可及，所以竞争肯定比以往更加激烈。”布特森说。

;

;这是她第二次尝试购买国泰机票。今年 5 月，她试图获得免费航班，这是政府吸引游客的“你好香港”活动的一部分，但当时也空手而归。

;

;布森在香港居住了距离2020年搬回英国已经六年了，她仍计划明年前往香港参加教女的洗礼。

;

;提到票价高昂，她说：“我明白为什么会有这样的情况发生。”增加，但目前的加价感觉像是航空公司正在利用忠诚的乘客。真是可惜了。”

;

;香港国泰航空推出10万张折扣机票，派发政府股息

;

;在香港生活了12年的英国放射技师尼克·拉坦吉(Nik Ratanji)计划明年前往澳大利亚和意大利，并表示更便宜的航班会对他的旅行有所帮助。

;

;“机票价格更高，需求旺盛，供应刚刚回升，人们必须找到这些小优惠来尝试和节省一些便士。”他在排队等候时告诉《华盛顿邮报》。

;

;折扣机票涵盖 34 个目的地，包括台湾高雄、东京、首尔、伦敦、悉尼和芝加哥，适用于 1 月至 6 月的旅行该航空公司表示，明年将受限制日期限制。

;

;该航空公司表示，特价机票起价为 1,220 港元，包括税费和其他费用。

;

;返回热门目的地伦敦的往返机票，起售价为 5,538 港元，与疫情前的价格类似。

;

;香港国泰航空 2023 年上半年盈利飙升至 43 亿港元

;

;Post 搜索非-一月第一周国泰航空往返经济舱折扣机票售价为港币12,563元。

;

;前往东京等热门目的地的折扣票价往返机票港币2,980元起。同期普通机票价格为港币6,585元。

;

;当被问及为何提供折扣机票时，发言人周三表示，航空公司随着服务的不断增加，不时推出促销活动。

;

;国泰航空上周公布 2023 年上半年净利润为 42.6 亿港元，此前连续三年亏损总计 337 亿港元。

;

;强劲的旅游需求加上高票价价格对国泰航空的收入有所帮助。

;

;香港国泰航空预计 2023 年上半年利润将高达 45 亿港元

;

;特别是，香港游客纷纷涌向日本，这一数字已达到6 月份的旅客人数几乎是疫情前水平的 90%，成为香港第四大旅客群体。

;

;捷成旅行社告诉《华盛顿邮报》，从香港出发的机票价格比从香港出发的机票贵 10% 至 50%。

;

;同时，香港航空在政府“你好香港”活动中举办了70万张机票抽奖活动，以吸引游客，并赠送1,000张经济舱机票。免费门票覆盖巴厘岛、曼谷、台北、首尔、东京、大阪等热门目的地。

;新加坡的一些移民家庭佣工面临雇主的“报复性指控”，通常是一份报告称，即使毫无根据，在问题解决之前他们也无法工作。

;

;该报告于周二发布，探讨了一些雇主如何利用向警方提出的这些指控作为对雇主的惩罚和报复措施移民经济人道主义组织（首页）的报告称，在某些情况下，这些指控是在移民家庭佣工离开工作岗位和雇主家后提出的。< /p>;

;在大多数情况下，这些工人被雇主指控犯罪，警方不会采取进一步行动，但他们的财务状况会受到影响，因为在调查期间他们不被允许工作。报告补充说，他们在家乡依赖收入的家人也遭受苦难。

;

;报告援引了备受瞩目的女佣 Parti Liyani 案件，她被关系密切的雇主指控盗窃，导致刑事指控和上诉法院澄清 Parti 之前的定罪。

;

;4 月，前樟宜机场集团主席刘文良 (Liew Mun Leong) 的儿子卡尔·刘启龙 (Karl Liew Kai Lung) 因向他人撒谎而被判处两周监禁。

;

;殴打、强奸、强迫喝狗尿：受虐待的印度尼西亚佣工打架

;

;根据其网站，Home 为家庭成员提供直接援助、住所和食物

;

;该报告基于从 Home 庇护所收集的 100 名移徙家庭佣工案例中收集的案例数据，这些案例被指控犯有各种2019 年 1 月至 2022 年 6 月期间发生的犯罪行为。

;

;庇护所是寻求法律追索或解决与雇主纠纷的工人的住所，其居民可以停留几天到更长的时间。 Home 网站称，一年。

;

;它补充说，这些工人在危机期间通常无法养活自己，也无法在新加坡居住。

;

;该报告特别指出关注“报复性指控”趋势。

;

;这是指原雇主在解除劳动者雇佣关系并离家出走后，对这些劳动者提出的指控。在五分之四的案件中，没有对工人采取进一步行动，因为该索赔被认为毫无根据。

;

;研究发现，85% 的指控是在工人到达工厂后提出的。庇护所的目的是盗窃，但只有 18% 的案件导致刑事指控。

;

;在某些情况下，被指控的妇女会收到警方的“严厉警告”，据 Home 称，这通常意味着她们即使她们没有被定罪，也不能在新加坡工作。

;

;报告中纳入了概述三名此类女性经历的案例研究，以强调霍姆所称的“移民所经历的法律和社会脆弱性”

;

;其中一位在报告中被列为“R1”的人，在被雇主拒绝遣返祖国一年后，决定前往 Home 收容所寻求帮助。< /p>;

;当R1回到雇主家取东西时，雇主指控她偷钱并报了警。

;

;调查结果，R1只得留下在警方结案且无需采取进一步行动后，他又在新加坡待了九个月，然后才返回家中。

;

;新加坡因偷窃雇主价值 47,000 美元的手表而入狱印尼女佣

;

;另一名移民霍姆说，被称为“R2”的家庭佣工在雇主家中受到严密监视。

;

;根据报告，R2 的卧室里有一个闭路电视 (CCTV) 摄像头，她是被指示这样做的保持全天候开启。她还被迫将手机交给雇主，以便他们可以阅读她所有的私人信息。

;

;R2 逃跑到 Home 庇护所寻求帮助后，她的雇主“追捕”她，要求他们赔偿她飞往新加坡的机票，以及未经通知而离开的额外罚款。

;

;据报道，他们还威胁要采取法律行动。

;

;她在收容所呆了一周后，R2 的雇主向警方报案报告称她偷了丢失的物品。

;

;在收容所呆了四个月后，该妇女被告知案件已经结束，无需采取进一步行动。

;

;“R3”的雇主” – 另一位移民家庭佣工 – 在发现 R3 决定对他的虐待行为“提起诉讼”后，愤怒地摔碎了手机。

;

;R3 的雇主告诉她向其支付 4,000 新元（2,936 美元）如果她想回家，就找他。

;

;该女子全额支付了费用，但随后雇主要求她支付更多费用。

;

;然后她逃跑并试图返回。回家后，却被雇主指控对其 37 岁有智力障碍的弟弟进行身体虐待。

;

;R3 在新加坡又被拘留了 10 个月。在此期间，报道称她的丈夫做了“大规模”手术，她的孩子再也无力上学。

;

;她的雇主继续骚扰她和她的丈夫，给他发信息说，警方的调查已经结束，她很快就会受到指控和惩罚。

;

;在经历了10个月的“巨大的情感困难”之后，案件没有采取进一步的行动。

;

;这个计划能否让结束对家政工人的“同住”规则吗？

;

;报告指出，当调查开始时，大多数被指控的工人都会获得特殊通行证，并且“除非自行决定，否则不得工作” ”。

;

;“实际上，仅仅受到指控就会使这些移徙家庭佣工的生计面临风险，因为这会中断他们的就业，并且他们会被无限期地拘留在有限的地点”，报告称。

;

;“这些证言也说明了受到报复指控的外来家政工人面临的真正风险。”

;

;伦敦引以为豪的大都会警察局正在努力应对影响伦敦警察部门的问题美国：警察之间共享的秘密短信暴露了其队伍中的种族主义。

;

;英国广播公司 (BBC) 周二报道称，有六名退休人员退休，这表明种族主义已在伦敦警察厅的最高层中肆虐。曾在部队外交保护小组工作过的警官因“严重冒犯性种族主义信息”而被指控犯有刑事罪。

;

;这些信息是在 2018 年至 2022 年间通过 WhatsApp 群组发送的，其中一些信息是据《新闻周刊》报道，这些消息涉及哈里王子和梅根·马克尔。其他人则针对受到英国有争议的庇护和移民政策影响的卢旺达人，以及最近遭受巴基斯坦洪水影响的人，该洪水造成近 1,700 人死亡。

;

;英国小报关于仇恨梅根·马克尔的专栏存在性别歧视，监督机构的发现

;

;伦敦警察厅的一份声明透露，这六名警官年龄都在 60 多岁，他们都曾在警察部队中担任过不同职务，但特别是在外交保护小组中服役，该小组后来更名为“外交保护小组” BBC 称，议会和外交保护司令部负责保护政府大楼、大使馆和官邸，包括唐宁街 10 号的首相官邸和议会所在地威斯敏斯特宫。

;

;该组织部署人员保护政府大楼、大使馆和官邸。

;

;声明称，这些指控是在大都会专业标准局进行调查之后提出的，该局是针对去年年底英国广播公司新闻之夜节目的曝光而发起的。声明称，根据 2003 年《通信法》的一项规定，这些警官被指控犯有罪行。

;

;领导大都会反腐败和滥用职权司令部的指挥官詹姆斯·哈曼 (James Harman) 告诉 BBC，“大都会警察中诚实的大多数人”官员们全力支持这项工作。”他说“他们厌倦了在警务工作中被少数人失望，他们意识到不良行为可能会对我们与我们所服务的社区的关系造成损害。”

;

;关于哈里和梅根，据《新闻周刊》报道，这并不是苏塞克斯公爵和公爵夫人第一次成为警察交换种族主义信息的对象。

;

;2022 年 7 月，伦敦警察厅法医服务部门的两名警官被解雇据《新闻周刊》当时报道，在对一名前同事涉嫌种族主义的 WhatsApp 消息进行了调查后。

;

;其中一条是在 2018 年哈利和梅根婚礼时发送的，其中显示了一个“golliwog”玩具的照片模因。 “golliwog”玩具是对黑人的种族主义漫画，照片的标题提到了梅根，她是混血儿。标题写道：“抢先预览梅根的婚纱。”

;

;当这两名警官被解雇时，另一名大都会指挥官乔恩·萨维尔 (Jon Savell) 当时表示：“这些卑鄙信息是在 2018 年在一个关闭了一小群警官之间的 WhatsApp 群组。我几乎不需要说，任何人的这种行为都是完全不能接受的，更不用说警察了。这三个人的行为是不可原谅的。”

;

;英国最大的警察部队“存在制度上的种族主义和性别歧视”

;

;哈里和梅根公开谈论了他们所说的她在警察手中遭受的种族主义。当她与哈里订婚以及嫁给英国王室时，英国媒体都报道了这一事件。

;

;这对夫妇于 2020 年逃离王室生活，此后在加利福尼亚州定居，他们还声称，英国内部存在种族主义。王室在 2021 年接受奥普拉·温弗瑞 (Oprah Winfrey) 采访时表示。

;

;他们表示，一位未透露姓名的家庭成员对他们未来孩子的肤色发表了种族不敏感的评论。哈里后来否认他的妻子曾称他家里的任何人为“种族主义者”，并表示对孩子肤色的评论是“无意识偏见”的一个例子。

;

;在旧金山湾区，爆料警察之间发送的数十条种族主义短信震惊了康特拉科斯塔县安提阿镇。对多名警官的指控（包括毒品交易、妨碍司法、以权威名义进行袭击和欺诈）的调查导致这些文本的发现和公布。

;2023年全球爆发的时尚潮流“多巴胺着装”吸引了数百万人的目光今年夏天，中国年轻人通过大胆、欢快的颜色选择唤起幸福感。

;

;多巴胺着装包括穿着具有引人注目的图案和高度饱和、鲜艳的颜色（如柠檬绿、柠檬黄和热色）的服装。粉红色。

;

;目的是提升情绪并放大喜悦感，类似于在我们体内释放化学多巴胺的效果，从而引发兴奋和幸福。

;

;具有潜在的心理学鲜艳的色彩可以唤起欢乐、放松和积极的情绪，多巴胺服饰还可以通过色彩起到“情绪治愈”的作用，让个人“穿上快乐”。

;

;今年5月初，一位著名的抖音网红，中文名“白周小熊”或“白天熊”，发布了一系列视频，在大陆社交媒体上将这一趋势推向了新的高度。

;

;在短短 10 秒的视频中，她迅速改变了态度六种不同的夏季服装，每一种都具有充满活力、明亮和迷人的色彩，她开玩笑地称之为“彩虹装扮”。

;

;网上的影响是深远的，该系列中的几个视频积累了超过仅在抖音上就有 500 万个赞。据飞瓜数据报道，白天熊在短短一个月内就新增了 280 万粉丝。

;

;这也引发了中国社交媒体平台上一系列相关视频和讨论。

;

;知名人物比如女演员虞书欣、纪梵希新任品牌大使、顶级网红易梦玲都曾参与多巴胺敷料，并在自己的社交媒体账号上分享。

;

;甚至一些消防员和医生的社交媒体账号

;

;5月21日，江西省消防局官方抖音账号分享了一段消防员四套多巴胺着装的视频。

;

;其中包括蓝色短袖制服、橙色救援​​制服、深绿色消防服和亮黄色危险品套装，视频获得了令人印象深刻的 260 万个赞。

;

;这一趋势甚至引发了人们对历史，正如中国网友声称的，2200多年前著名的兵马俑就是多巴胺敷料的早期例子。

;

;由于兵马俑长期浸泡在地下以及暴露在空气中的氧化作用，今天游客看到的武士缺乏原来的颜色。

;

;然而，当它们被创造出来时，工匠们用各种鲜艳的色彩装饰它们，主要有八种颜色——红、绿、蓝、紫、黄、粉红，黑白。

;

;一位小红书网上评论者表示：“所以兵马俑实际上是最早采用多巴胺敷料的人！”

;

;不出所料，这一趋势激起了新的消费需求并提振了快时尚品牌的销量。

;

;优衣库以其舒适休闲的风格和柔和的色彩而闻名，今年夏天以实惠的价格推出了一系列色彩鲜艳的背心、短裤和裙子。

;

; >;

;服装选择往往反映了更广泛的生活方式选择的转变。

;

;此前，“normcore”风格在中国流行，其特点是朴实无华、外观普通的服装，适合那些渴望简约和超然的人们

;

;Britney Spears' husband Sam Asghari has filed for divorce from the superstar 14 months after a they were married, a person familiar with the filing said late Wednesday.

;

;The person, who is close to Asghari but not authorised to speak publicly, confirmed the filing happened on Wednesday, hours after several outlets including TMZ and People magazine reported the couple had separated.

;

;An email sent to a Spears representative was not immediately returned. Court records in Los Angeles and Ventura counties did not show where the case had been filed.

;

;Spears married Asghari at her home in Thousand Oaks, California, on June 9, 2022 in front of guests including Selena Gomez, Drew Barrymore, Paris Hilton and Madonna, in a wedding seen as a milestone in her newly reclaimed life after the dissolution just six months earlier of the court conservatorship that controlled her life for more than 13 years.

;

;'Best day ever': Britney Spears' conservatorship ends after 13 years

;

;The pop superstar met and began dating Asghari, a model and actor, when he appeared in her video for the song Slumber Party in 2016.

;

;She cited her desire to marry Asghari as among the reasons she wanted an end to the constraining conservatorship, which she said was preventing it. The two announced their engagement in September of 2021 as it became clear she would be freed from the conservatorship – which was ended that November.

;

;Spears said she and Asghari lost a baby early in her pregnancy in May 2022, about a month before they married.

;

;Reports of the couple's struggles had increased in recent months.

;

;Their marriage is the first for the 29-year-old Asghari and the third for the 41-year-old singer. She was married for less than three days in 2004 to childhood friend Jason Alexander, who attempted to crash her wedding to Asghari and was later convicted of misdemeanour trespassing and battery.

;

;In 2004, she wed dancer Kevin Federline.他们的三年婚姻正值媒体的密切关注和斯皮尔斯的心理健康问题日益严重之际。 Federline is the father of her two teenage sons, and has custody of the boys.

;

;She would be placed in the conservatorship run by her father in 2008. She did well under the arrangement at first, continuing to release records, make videos, and perform live, including a major concert residency in Las Vegas. But as she appeared less in public, fans began to demand that the court #FreeBritney, in what would eventually become a major movement.

;

;Since the conservatorship ended, Spears has put out music, including a collaboration with Elton John in 2022, but has not performed live in years, nor announced plans to do so.

;

;Her memoir, The Woman in Me, is scheduled to be released in October.

;Hong Kong's first post-pandemic food expo opened its doors on Thursday to more than 1,000 visitors eager to snap up mouth-watering discounts and taste a smorgasbord of exotic fare at the annual flagship event in Wan Chai.

;

;Visitors, mostly elderly residents, told the Post they were excited to sample food again, noting the Hong Kong Food Expo 2023 was livelier and more crowded than last year's edition. Taste tests were not allowed at the previous event amid Covid-transmission fears.

;

;Jacky Li, who started queuing at noon on Wednesday, was first in line at the Convention and Exhibition Centre.

;

;“I want to snatch the cans of abalones,” the IT worker, 40, said. “我很高兴今年样品又回来了。 I want to try coffee, cheeses, ham and other Japanese snacks.”

;

;He said he expected to spend about HK$1,000 (US$128) at the fair, 20 per cent more than his budget last year.

;Exhibitors at Hong Kong Food Expo hope return of samples will help drum up business

;

;Retiree Yu Sau-ying, 74, and her team emerged victorious and walked away with 500 cans. “今年我可以每顿饭都吃鲍鱼了。”赛后她兴奋地说。 “There's too many cans for me, I'll give some away to my children as well.”

;

;

;“Our dried braised mushrooms are very popular.过去，每 10 个人尝试过，就有 7 个人会购买。去年，每 10 个参观者中，只有两三个人购买过。 So we're very excited for the return of sampling,” he said.

;

;Samples are back at Hong Kong Food Expo amid concerns about Japanese imports

;

;He added while the opening on Thursday morning was quieter than in previous years, he was confident visitor traffic would peak over the weekend and the new Exhibition Centre MTR station would bring in more customers.

;

;Ko, a 70-year-old retiree in the queue for a free sample of dumplings at the fair, said he did not visit the expo last year but returned this time because he could try tasting food.

;

;“I didn't bother coming last year because of the pandemic.如果我不能进行口味测试，那么食品博览会还有什么意义呢？” he said.

;

;He said he was looking forward to buying pantry staples such as frozen dumplings, pointing to the new MTR station that made his commute from Kowloon easier as he did not have to transfer trains or walk from Wan Chai station.

;

;Hong Kong Food Expo visitors queue for days to get big prizes and bargains

;

;The expo will run alongside a beauty and home appliance fair till August 21, as well as a tea and traditional Chinese medicine fair that will last till Saturday, with more than 1,800 exhibitors expected across the three events.

; Thu, 17 Aug 2023 12:50:02 +0800 AI-generated news is not publishable under AP guidelines as newsrooms introduce rules for using the new techhttps://www.scmp.com/tech/tech-trends/article/3231369/ai-generated-news-not-publishable-under-ap-guidelines-newsrooms-introduce-rules-using-new-tech?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.08.17 12:40;
;;

;The Associated Press has issued guidelines on artificial intelligence, saying the tool cannot be used to create publishable content and images for the news service while encouraging staff members to become familiar with the technology.

;

;AP is one of a handful of news organizations that have begun to set rules on how to integrate fast-developing tech tools like ChatGPT into their work. The service will couple this on Thursday with a chapter in its influential Stylebook that advises journalists how to cover the story, complete with a glossary of terminology.

;

;“Our goal is to give people a good way to understand how we can do a little experimentation but also be safe,” said Amanda Barrett, vice-president of news standards and inclusion at AP.

;

;China sets out new rules for generative AI with an emphasis on 'core socialist values'

;

;The journalism think tank Poynter Institute, saying it was a “transformational moment”, urged news organizations this spring to create standards for AI's use, and share the policies with readers and viewers.

;

;Generative AI has the ability to create text, images, audio and video on command, but isn't yet fully capable of distinguishing between fact and fiction

;

;As a result, AP said material produced by artificial intelligence should be vetted carefully, just like material from any other news source. Similarly, AP said a photo, video or audio segment generated by AI should not be used, unless the altered material is itself the subject of a story.

;

;That's in line with the tech magazine Wired, which said it does not publish stories generated by AI, “except when the fact that it's AI-generated is the point of the whole story”.

;

;“Your stories must be completely written by you,” Nicholas Carlson, Insider editor-in-chief, wrote in a note to employees that was shared with readers. “You are responsible for the accuracy, fairness, originality and quality of every word in your stories.”

;

;Highly-publicised cases of AI-generated “hallucinations”, or made-up facts, make it important that consumers know that standards are in place to “make sure the content they're reading, watching and listening to is verified, credible and as fair as possible”, Poynter said in an editorial.

;

;News organisations have outlined ways that generative AI can be useful short of publishing.例如，它可以帮助美联社的编辑整理作品中的故事摘要，并发送给订阅者。 《连线》称，它可以帮助编辑创造头条新闻或产生故事创意。 Carlson said AI could be asked to suggest possible edits to make a story concise and more readable, or to come up with possible questions for an interview.

;

;AP has experimented with simpler forms of artificial intelligence for a decade, using it to create short news stories out of sports box scores or corporate earnings reports. That's important experience, Barrett said, but “we still want to enter this new phase cautiously, making sure we protect our journalism and protect our credibility”.

;

;ChatGPT-maker OpenAI and The Associated Press last month announced a deal for the artificial intelligence company to license AP's archive of news stories that it uses for training purposes.

;

;News organizations are concerned about their material being used by AI companies without permission or payment. The News Media Alliance, representing hundreds of publishers, issued a statement of principles designed to protect its members' intellectual property rights.

;

;Alibaba Cloud open sources some of its AI chatbot technology

;

;Some journalists have expressed worry that artificial intelligence could eventually replace jobs done by humans and is a matter of keen interest, for example, in contract talks between AP and its union, the News Media Guild. The guild hasn't had the chance to fully analyse what they mean, said Vin Cherwoo, the union's president.

;

;“We were encouraged by some provisions and have questions on others,” Cherwoo said.

;

;With safeguards in place, AP wants its journalists to become familiar with the technology, since they will need to report stories about it in coming years, Barrett said.

;

;AP's Stylebook – a road map of journalistic practices and rules for use of terminology in stories – will explain in the chapter due to be released Thursday many of the factors that journalists should consider when writing about the technology.

;

;“The artificial intelligence story goes far beyond business and technology,” the AP says. “它还涉及政治、娱乐、教育、体育、人权、经济、平等与不平等、国际法和许多其他问题。 Successful AI stories show how these tools are affecting many areas of our lives.”

;

;The chapter includes a glossary of terminology, including machine learning, training data, face recognition and algorithmic bias.

;

;Little of it should be considered the final word on the topic. A committee exploring guidance on the topic meets monthly, Barrett said.

;

;“I fully expect we'll have to update the guidance every three months because the landscape is shifting,” she said.

;A showdown between the Australian Labor government and its rank and file over the government's nuclear-powered Aukus submarine deal is set to unfold at a key decision-making conference this week as domestic disapproval of Aukus grows.

;

;Following the March announcement of an agreement with the United States and Britain for Australia to acquire up to eight submarines, and the necessary military and civilian training, the government's party members, anti-war groups and many unions have become increasingly agitated.

;

;They say the Aukus deal could cede Australia's sovereignty to the US, unravel the country's non-nuclear commitments and hurt the pockets of taxpayers because of the A$368 billion (US$237 billion) cost over the next 30 years.

;

;Similar concerns have also been echoed by neighbouring countries including Malaysia and Indonesia, mainly about how the two-year-old Aukus threesome could unsettle the region's security or start an arms race, although analysts say the Albanese government's diplomacy efforts have managed to assuage some of these reservations.

;

;Domestic anxieties about the Aukus military pact and the underlying submarines purchase – particularly from party members – have, however, reached a crescendo ahead of Labor's key triennial conference starting Thursday, prompting Defence Minister Richard Marles and Defence Industry Minister Pat Conroy to hold a special video briefing on Monday night to try to placate members and defuse tension.

;

;'A past mindset': Aukus upends Australia's attempted US-China balancing act

;

;The conference, which locks down party policies that shape how the government manages Australia, is largely a rubber-stamp of what has already been fought out and agreed upon.

;

;However, more than 50 branches have passed motions for the government to review or withdraw from the Aukus alliance and groups within the party such as Labor Against War have consequently managed to force a debate on Aukus into the conference's agenda.

;

;Labor Against War acknowledges the 50 branches – out of hundreds – is just a start and says “it is inappropriate to endorse Aukus given its problematic features”.

;

;“There are so many things wrong with Aukus … putting Australia on a 'war footing' with our main trading partner just makes no sense,” said Marcus Strom, a spokesman for Labor Against War and a former press secretary for the Albanese government.

;

;He said Aukus is seen as “crossing a line on nuclear power that has been at the heart of Labor principle” and would “create a loophole in the nuclear non-proliferation treaty [in force since 1970] for non-nuclear-armed countries to access weapons-grade uranium”.

;

;The government admits it has no solution for nuclear waste, he added.

;

;The potential erosion of Australia's sovereignty is also worrying some amid people like Kurt Campbell, US President Biden's so-called Asia tsar, telling Washington that submarines provided to Australia “are not lost”, Strom said.

;

;Campbell said the vessels were merely deployed to “the closest possible allied force” during a discussion with the US-based Centre for Strategic and International Studies in June.

;

;“This clearly implies the US expects to retain control of the submarines,” Strom said.

;

;Party members and the Australian public alike have spoken up publicly about the current government's detraction from Labor values, values traditionally seen in the commitment towards peacebuilding and the scepticism of US militarism.

;

;Prominent members like former prime minister Paul Keating and former foreign minister Bob Carr have been openly critical of Aukus.

;

;Australia faces tough task soothing Asia anxieties over Aukus subs: analysts

;

;A debate is now set for Friday morning to discuss the removal of “Aukus” from Labor's platform on defence, but not before a major protest takes place outside the conference.

;

;Strom's Labor Against War, trade unions – the grass roots of the party – and peace groups will be rallying against Aukus and a potential war with China. The demonstrations have also been backed by 20 organisations.

;

;It is not the first display of dissent against Aukus.

;

;In May, Labor unionists rallied at Wollongong's Port Kembla, near Sydney, to rule out the site as a future base for the submarines.

;

;“Many Australians are starting to understand that the decision of whether or not to go to war has been taken away from the Australian government and, by virtue of that, the Australian people,” Arthur Rorris, head of the South Coast Labour Council, a union, told local media after the Port Kembla rally in May.

;

;“There's clearly been a coup in defence policy. Slowly but surely they shifted the focus of our defence from defending Australia to defending US economic interests in the South China Sea.”

;

;In March, Michele O'Neil, the president of the Australian Council of Trade Unions – which brings 36 unions together – said they backed a “nuclear-free defence policy”.

;

;Various debates and rallies have been held across the country by groups like the Australian Anti-Aukus Coalition, Australians for War Powers Reform and the Independent and Peaceful Australia Network, which conducted a peace speaking tour earlier this month that was joined by representatives from the Pacific Ocean's island of Guam – a US territory since its capture from Spain in 1898 – and Japan's island of Okinawa. There are thousands of American troops in both places.

;

;In March, Nobel Peace Prize winner, the International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons (ICAN) civil society coalition campaigned against Aukus, saying it had moved Australia from a non-nuclear state to a position of “provocation” supporting the US in a potential war in northeast Asia.

;

;In May, high-profile politicians, former military leaders and academic experts took out a newspaper advertisement calling for a parliamentary inquiry, saying “questions about Aukus remain unanswered”.

;

;What to know about Australia's Aukus subs and why it's causing anxiety in Asia

;

;More than 100 university academics penned an open letter decrying Aukus that same month. “The government has not made clear how Aukus will translate into a safer Australia,” the letter said.

;

;But all of this does not mean there will be significant victory against Aukus on Friday, said one of the signatories, Scott Burchill, a honorary fellow in international relations at Deakin University.

;

;“If anything, Albanese has been more pro-Washington than [former prime minister Scott] Morrison. He knows he doesn't have to worry about significant factional opposition,” he said, referring to full support for Aukus from both the left and right factions of the party thus far.

;

;Opposition to Aukus might not gain traction anyway as it “encompasses such an incoherent mishmash of grumbles”, said Matthew Sussex, a fellow at the Strategic and Defence Studies Centre at the Australian National University.

;

;Labor Against War's Strom is aware many party members will be loyal to the government and keep their counsel on Aukus, but he says the debate on Friday is just the beginning.

;

;“The dangers of Aukus are too important for us not to speak out,” he said.
